questions.text: Which physiological mechanism best describes the Frank-Starling law of the heart?

options.label: A
options.text: The heart's stroke volume decreases as myocardial fiber length increases.

options.label: B
options.text: The heart's stroke volume is regulated primarily by sympathetic nervous system stimulation.

options.label: C
options.text: The heart's stroke volume increases in response to increased end-diastolic volume due to the length-tension relationship of cardiac muscle fibers.

options.label: D
options.text: The heart's stroke volume remains unchanged regardless of changes in venous return, due to intrinsic pacemaker activity

questions.correct_answer: C. The heart's stroke volume increases in response to increased end-diastolic volume due to the length-tension relationship of cardiac muscle fibers.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding erythropoietin is not true?

options.label: A
options.text: It is majorly produced by the liver

options.label: B
options.text: Major stimulus for its production is hypoxia

options.label: C
options.text: It acts on JAK-STAT pathway

options.label: D
options.text: The maximum erythropoietin receptor density is seen on CFU-E

questions.correct_answer: A. It is majorly produced by the liver

questions.text: Which of the following accurately describes the unique properties of "funny channels" in the heart's nodal tissue?

options.label: A
options.text: "Funny channels" open during depolarization and are primarily permeable to calcium (Ca 2+ ) ions.

options.label: B
options.text: "Funny channels" close upon hyperpolarization and restrict sodium (Na + ) influx.

options.label: C
options.text: "Funny channels" open upon hyperpolarization, allowing both sodium (Na + ) and potassium (K + ) ions to pass through.

options.label: D
options.text: "Funny channels" are activated by parasympathetic stimulation, speeding up the heart rate.

questions.correct_answer: C. "Funny channels" open upon hyperpolarization, allowing both sodium (Na + ) and potassium (K + ) ions to pass through.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms is primarily responsible for the relaxation of myocardial cells?

options.label: A
options.text: Opening of L-type calcium channels

options.label: B
options.text: Activity of the SERCA2 pump

options.label: C
options.text: Blocking the sodium-calcium exchanger

options.label: D
options.text: Dephosphorylation of phospholamban

questions.correct_answer: B. Activity of the SERCA2 pump

questions.text: Given below is the action potential of a cardiac muscle fiber. Which of the following gives rise to Phase 2 depicted in the image?

options.label: A
options.text: Closure of Na+ channels and opening of K+ channel

options.label: B
options.text: Closure of the Ca2+ channels and a slow, delayed increase of K+ efflux

options.label: C
options.text: Opening of voltage-gated Na+ channels.

options.label: D
options.text: Opening of slow L-type voltage-gated Ca2+ channels and efflux of K+ though rectifier channels.

questions.correct_answer: D. Opening of slow L-type voltage-gated Ca2+ channels and efflux of K+ though rectifier channels.
questions.explanation:
PHASES

OPENING AND CLOSURE OF CHANNELS

Phase 0- Depolarization

Opening of voltage-gated Na+ channels(Option C)

Phase 1- Initial rapid repolarization

Closure of Na+ channels

Opening of K+ channel (Option A)

Phase 2- Plateau phase

Slower but prolonged opening of L-type voltage-gated Ca2+ channels 

K+ channel also remains open.

Phase 3- Late rapid repolarization

Closure of the Ca2+ channels 

Slow, delayed increase of K+ efflux (Option B)

Phase 4- Baseline

Resting Membrane Potential About −80 to −90 millivolts.

questions.text: Arrange the following according to the conduction times (conduction delay) in the heart in ascending order (lowest time to highest time) a. SA node to AV node b. AV node to bundle of His c. Apex to the base of the heart d. Bundle of his to interventricular septum

options.label: A
options.text: c, b, a, d

options.label: B
options.text: c, a, d, b

options.label: C
options.text: b, a, d, c

options.label: D
options.text: d, a, b, c

questions.correct_answer: B. c, a, d, b
questions.explanation:
Apex to the base of the heart

0.02 seconds

SA node to AV node

0.03 seconds

Interventricular septum to the apex of the heart

0.03 seconds

Bundle of his to interventricular septum

0.04 seconds

AV node to bundle of His

0.10 seconds

questions.text: Which of the following statements about platelets are true?

options.label: A
options.text: Alpha granules contain clotting factors and platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF)

options.label: B
options.text: Splenectomy causes a decrease in the platelet count

options.label: C
options.text: Interleukins IL-2, IL-4, IL-5, and IL-7 are involved in stimulating platelet production

options.label: D
options.text: Thrombopoietin is produced exclusively by megakaryocytes and regulates platelet production

questions.correct_answer: A. Alpha granules contain clotting factors and platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF)
questions.explanation:
Platelets

General Description

Small, granulated, non-nucleated discs important for hemostasis

Size

1-4 µm in diameter

Concentration in Blood

150,000 - 450,000/µL

Half-life

~4 days

Origin

Formed from megakaryocytes in the bone marrow

Distribution

60-75% in circulation; the remainder mainly in the spleen

Splenectomy Effect

Causes an increase in platelet count (thrombocytosis) (Option B)

Thrombopoietin

Produced by liver and kidneys; regulates platelet production (Option D)

Membrane Receptors

For collagen, ADP, von Willebrand factor and fibrinogen

Cytoplasmic Components

Actin, myosin, glycogen, lysosomes and granules

Granules
  • Alpha granules: Soluble coagulation proteins (vWF, Factor V, II), adhesion molecule, growth factor (IGF, PDGF, TGF-β, platelet factor 4), Integrin, Cytokines (Option A)
  • Dense granules: ADP, ATP, Calcium, Serotonin

Response to Injury

Adhere to exposed collagen and von Willebrand factor; release granule contents upon activation

Deficiency Effect

Thrombocytopenic purpura (easy bruising, multiple subcutaneous hemorrhages)

Interleukins

IL-1, IL-3, IL-6, IL-11 stimulate platelet production (Option C)

Factors increasing platelet synthesis

Inflammation, thrombopoietin and IL-1, IL-3, IL-6, IL-11

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with a right shift in Arneth count?

options.label: A
options.text: Active tuberculosis

options.label: B
options.text: Acute progressive infections

options.label: C
options.text: Bone marrow suppression

options.label: D
options.text: Bone marrow stimulation

questions.correct_answer: C. Bone marrow suppression
questions.explanation:
Classification of Neutrophil
  • Class I: Myelocytes and neutrophils with indented or horseshoe-shaped nuclei. (5%)
  • Class II: Neutrophils with bilobed nuclei. (35%)
  • Class III: Neutrophils with tri-lobed nuclei. (41%)
  • Class IV: Neutrophils with four-lobed nuclei. (17%)
  • Class V: Neutrophils with five or more lobes in their nuclei. (2%)

Toxic Conditions
  • Fewer cells in Classes IV and V indicate a left-sided shift
  • Active tuberculosis often shows a left shift.      (Option A)
  • Other infections showing a left shift may have superimposed tuberculosis

Extrinsic Factors Influencing Arneth Count
  • Certain drugs, tissue extracts, and hormones.
  • Trauma , various forms of radiation.
  • Induction of anesthesia.

Infections and Arneth Count
  • Acute progressive infections: Notable left shift. (Option B)
  • As infection subsides: Less marked left shift, may shift to the right.
  • Chronic infections: Other features like lymphocytosis come into range.

Normal Neutrophil Distribution

N1 and N3 constitute most neutrophils in peripheral blood.

Bone Marrow Stimulation

Presence of younger neutrophils (N1 and N2) indicates stimulation of bone marrow (shift to the left).      (Option D)

Bone Marrow Suppression

Presence of older cells (N4 and N5) indicates suppression of bone marrow (shift to right) (Option C)

Hypersegmented Neutrophil

Seen in megaloblastic anemia due to folate and vitamin B12 deficiency (shift to right)

questions.text: According to the Monro-Kellie doctrine, which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the intracranial pressure (ICP) homeostasis?

options.label: A
options.text: An increase in cerebrospinal fluid volume can be compensated by a decrease in brain tissue volume

options.label: B
options.text: An increase in blood volume can be offset by a decrease in cerebrospinal fluid volume

options.label: C
options.text: The sum of volumes of brain tissue, blood, and cerebrospinal fluid remains constant

options.label: D
options.text: A significant increase in one intracranial component always leads to a proportional increase in ICP

questions.correct_answer: A. An increase in cerebrospinal fluid volume can be compensated by a decrease in brain tissue volume

questions.text: Which of the following statements about myocardial muscle tension is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Preload primarily affects the velocity of muscle shortening

options.label: B
options.text: Afterload does not affect the duration of systole

options.label: C
options.text: Increasing preload leads to decreased muscle tension

options.label: D
options.text: The force-velocity relationship in cardiac muscle is inverse and hyperbolic

questions.correct_answer: D. The force-velocity relationship in cardiac muscle is inverse and hyperbolic

questions.text: What is the duration of the cardiac cycle for a heart rate of 180 beats per minute?

options.label: A
options.text: 0.5 seconds

options.label: B
options.text: 0.75 seconds

options.label: C
options.text: 0.33 seconds

options.label: D
options.text: 0.66 seconds

questions.correct_answer: C. 0.33 seconds
questions.explanation:
Phase

Sub-Phase

Key Events

Systole

Isovolumetric Contraction
  • Ventricles begin to contract
  • Ranges from closure of AV valves (mitral and tricuspid) till opening of semilunar valves.
  • First heart sound appears.
  • No blood volume change in ventricles
 

Ventricular Ejection
  • Has 2 phases- Rapid ejection phase and Reduced ejection phase.
  • Ventricular pressure exceeds aortic and pulmonary pressure
  • Aortic and pulmonary valves open
  • Blood ejected into aorta and pulmonary artery
  • Ventricular volume decreases
  • Ends with the closure of the aortic valve.

Diastole

Isovolumetric Relaxation
  • Ventricles relax
  • Ventricular pressure drops
  • Aortic and pulmonary valves close
  • No blood volume change in ventricles
  • Second heart sounds appears.
  • Ends with the opening of AV valves.
 

Rapid Filling
  • AV valves (mitral and tricuspid) open
  • Blood flows rapidly from atria to ventricles
  • Ventricular volume increases rapidly
  • Third heart sound appears.
 

Diastasis
  • Blood flow from atria to ventricles slows
  • No change in the atrial and ventricular pressure.
  • Ventricular volume increases slowly
 

Atrial Systole
  • Atria contract
  • Additional blood pushed into ventricles
  • Ventricular volume increases slightly
  • End-diastolic volume (EDV) reached
  • Fourth heart sound is produced.

questions.text: A patient with massive blood loss is found to have increased sympathetic nervous system activity, resulting in elevated blood pressure. Which combination of factors primarily triggers the central nervous system (CNS) ischemic response?

options.label: A
options.text: Hypoxia and hypercapnia

options.label: B
options.text: Hypoxia and hypocapnia

options.label: C
options.text: Hypoglycemia and hypoxia

options.label: D
options.text: Hypoglycemia and hypercapnia

questions.correct_answer: A. Hypoxia and hypercapnia

questions.text: According to the Fick principle, which of the following is essential for calculating cardiac output?

options.label: A
options.text: Measurement of the patient’s blood pressure before and after exercise

options.label: B
options.text: Determination of the oxygen uptake by the lungs and the arteriovenous oxygen content difference

options.label: C
options.text: Assessment of the patient’s heart rate and electrocardiographic findings

options.label: D
options.text: Injection of a contrast dye and measurement of its concentration in the blood over time

questions.correct_answer: B. Determination of the oxygen uptake by the lungs and the arteriovenous oxygen content difference
questions.explanation:
Method

Principle

Measurement Basis

Key Considerations

Fick Principle

Oxygen uptake and arteriovenous difference

Oxygen content in blood

Accurate in steady states

Indicator Dilution Method

Indicator concentration dilution

Injected dye or tracer

Requires precise indicator handling

Echocardiography

Ultrasound visualization and flow velocity

Stroke volume estimation

Non-invasive, real-time data

Thoracic Electrical Bioimpedance

Electrical impedance changes

Impedance fluctuations

Sensitive to external factors

questions.text: A patient undergoing PCI for myocardial infarction suddenly develops bradycardia, hypotension, and episodes of apnoea.Which of the following reflexes is most likely mediated by chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region?

options.label: A
options.text: Cushing reflex

options.label: B
options.text: Bainbridge reflex

options.label: C
options.text: Bezold-Jarisch reflex

options.label: D
options.text: Baroreceptor reflex

questions.correct_answer: C. Bezold-Jarisch reflex

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly applies the law of Laplace in cardiovascular physiology?

options.label: A
options.text: Capillaries are prone to rupture due to high wall tension.

options.label: B
options.text: Dilated hearts have to work harder due to increased myocardial tension.

options.label: C
options.text: Increased flow velocity in narrow vessels reduces distending pressure.

options.label: D
options.text: The total energy in a tube or blood vessel remains constant.

questions.correct_answer: B. Dilated hearts have to work harder due to increased myocardial tension.
questions.explanation:
Principle

Definition

Applications

Law of Laplace

The tension in the wall of a cylinder is equal to the product of transmural pressure and radius divided by wall thickness.

T= P.r/ 2w ( T= Tension, P= Transmural pressure, r= Radius, w= Wall thickness)

Capillaries: Low tension in walls due to small radius, resistant to rupture. (Option A)

Dilated Hearts: Increased radius requires more tension, increasing cardiac workload.(Option B)

Bernoulli Principle

The total energy in a tube or blood vessel (kinetic energy + potential energy) remains constant. (Option D)


 

Pressure Measurement: Lower side arm pressure in a T tube due to kinetic energy of flow. Atherosclerotic Plaques: Increased flow velocity in narrow vessels reduces distending pressure, maintaining vessel narrowing. (Option C)

questions.text: In the jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform, which of the following statements accurately describes the "c wave"?

options.label: A
options.text: The "c wave" is caused by atrial systole

options.label: B
options.text: The "c wave" arises from the increase in atrial pressure during isovolumetric ventricular contraction

options.label: C
options.text: The "c wave" corresponds to the rise in atrial pressure as blood fills the atria

options.label: D
options.text: The "c wave" is influenced by the fluctuations in venous pressure caused by respiration

questions.correct_answer: B. The "c wave" arises from the increase in atrial pressure during isovolumetric ventricular contraction
questions.explanation:
a wave
  • Caused by atrial systole. (Option A ruled out)
  • Atrial contraction results in a temporary halt in venous inflow.
  • Some blood flows back into the veins, causing a rise in venous pressure.

c wave
  • Arises from the increase in atrial pressure during isovolumetric ventricular contraction. (Option B)
  • Pressure is transmitted through the closed and bulging tricuspid valve.

x descent
  • Ventricular systole pulls the tricuspid valve down

v wave
  • Corresponds to the rise in atrial pressure as blood fills the atria. (Option C ruled out)
  • Occurs during diastole while the tricuspid valve is still closed.

y descent
  • Opening of tricuspid valve causing emptying of right atrium into ventricle

questions.text: In the His bundle electrogram (HBE), what does the H wave denote?

options.label: A
options.text: Atrial depolarization

options.label: B
options.text: Ventricular depolarization

options.label: C
options.text: Depolarization of the His bundle

options.label: D
options.text: Repolarization of the ventricles

questions.correct_answer: C. Depolarization of the His bundle
questions.explanation:
Waveforms in the His Bundle Electrogram
 

A Wave

(Option A)

The A wave represents atrial depolarization.
 

H Wave

(Option C)

The H wave represents depolarization of the His bundle’s upper part.
 

V Wave:

(Option B)

The V wave represents ventricular depolarization.
 

Intervals in the His Bundle Electrogram
 

P-A Interval
  • The PA interval is the time from the onset of the P wave on the surface ECG to the onset of the A wave on the His bundle electrogram.
  • The PA interval typically ranges from 25 to 55 milliseconds.
 

A-H Interval
  • The A-H interval is the time between the onset of the A wave and the onset of the H wave.
  • Typically ranges from 50 to 120 milliseconds.
  • This interval represents conduction time through the AV node. A prolonged A-H interval suggests AV nodal conduction delay.
 

H-V Interval
  • Typically ranges from 35 to 55 milliseconds.
  • This interval represents conduction time through the His-Purkinje system. A prolonged H-V interval suggests an infranodal conduction delay or block.

questions.text: Which of the following can be considered as Left axis deviation?
Which of the following statements is true regarding ECG leads?

options.label: A
options.text: Chest leads are bipolar limb leads- horizontal plane.

options.label: B
options.text: Positive end of the voltmeter is connected to the Wilson terminal.

options.label: C
options.text: In lead II the negative end is the right arm

options.label: D
options.text: Augmented limb lead is bipolar

questions.correct_answer: C. In lead II the negative end is the right arm
questions.explanation:
Leads

Number of Leads

Bipolar limb leads

Lead I, Lead II, Lead III

Augmented unipolar limb leads (option D)

aVR, aVL, aVF

Precordial/ chest unipolar leads

V1, V2, V3, V4, V5 ,V6

Bipolar

Unipolar
  • Both the electrodes are active
  • It is the difference between positive - negative
  • Located on the frontal/ coronal plane.(option A)
  • One electrode is the active or recording electrode and the other one is the indifferent electrode.
  • There are six unipolar chest leads and three unipolar limb leads( augmented limb leads)
  • Located on the frontal/ coronal plane.(option A)

Leads

Voltmeter connection

Volage vector direction

Negative end

Positive end

Lead I

Right arm

Left arm

Negative to positive

Lead II

Right arm (option C)

Left foot

Negative to positive

Lead III

Left arm

Left foot

Positive to negative

Leads

Position

V1

4th intercostal space, right sternal border

V2

4th intercostal space, left sternal border

V3

Midway between V2 and V4

V4

5th intercostal space, midclavicular line

V5

5th intercostal space, anterior axillary line

V6

5th intercostal space, midaxillary line

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the Class I antiarrhythmics on the cardiac action potential?

options.label: A
options.text: Prolong the repolarization phase by blocking potassium channels

options.label: B
options.text: Class Ib decrease the QT interval

options.label: C
options.text: Class Ic are the most potent

options.label: D
options.text: Reduce the rate of depolarization during phase 0

questions.correct_answer: A. Prolong the repolarization phase by blocking potassium channels
questions.explanation:
Class Ia

Class Ib

Class Ic

Degree of block

Moderate

Mild

Marked (option C)

QT interval

Prolong

Decrease (option B)

No effect
